items.title: Preventing premature deaths through polygenic risk scores
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-68129-x Via an integrative modelling approach that combines population and clinical trial data, the authors find that polygenic risk score-based screening would reduce premature mortality across seven commonly screened conditions.

items.title: Interfacial water regulation on Ru single atoms doped Co<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub> toward efficient electrochemical hydrogenation of quinoxaline
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68740-6 Electrochemical hydrogenation of quinoxaline is a promising alternative to traditional methods but is limited by low current density and Faradaic efficiency. Here, the authors report a Ru single atoms doped Co3O4 nanosheet catalyst that regulates interfacial water to achieve excellent performance.

items.title: Community benchmarking and evaluation of human unannotated microprotein detection by mass spectrometry based proteomics
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-68002-x Several recent publications have attempted to detect novel unannotated microproteins using mass spectrometry proteomics. Here, the authors reassess these claimed microprotein detections, finding that many are poorly supported, while a subset represents likely genuine discoveries of novel proteins.

items.title: Dynamic signature of activity-stability tradeoff in lactamase evolution
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68620-z Enzymes adapt by sampling new conformations while balancing destabilizing effects of mutations. Here, the authors reveal how TEM-1 β-lactamase acquires cefotaxime resistance through reshaping of dynamic conformational ensembles and localized stability networks, offering insight into the molecular framework of the activity-stability tradeoff.

items.title: Low intensity vibration with zoledronate reduces musculoskeletal weakness and adiposity in estrogen deprived female mice
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68522-0 In young, estrogen-deprived female mice, the authors show that daily low-intensity vibration protected bone, muscle and fat metabolism. This treatment also enhanced bisphosphonate outcomes, strengthening the skeleton to counter adverse effects of cancer therapy on musculoskeletal tissue.

items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00163-1 Lawmakers announce legislation that would actually increase funding for basic research by more than 2%.

items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00090-1 From education to pandemic preparedness and public health, the past year has seen huge stress put on US science.

items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00102-0 The United States is leaving some of the world’s oldest and most influential scientific networks involved in biodiversity research, climate science and conservation. items.title: Dynamical simulations of many-body quantum chaos on a quantum computer
items.summary: Nature Physics, Published online: 20 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41567-025-03144-9 Studying many-body quantum chaos on current quantum hardware is hindered by noise and limited scalability. Now it is shown that a superconducting processor, combined with error mitigation, can accurately simulate dual-unitary circuit dynamics.

items.title: Strong correlations and superconductivity in the supermoiré lattice

Now, the effects of a supermoiré lattice on the band structure and transport properties of twisted trilayer graphene is investigated.

items.title: Endothelin-3 and T-type Ca<sup>2+</sup> channels drive enteric neural crest cell calcium activity, contractility and migration
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 20 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-68121-5 Neural crest cells migrate in the embryo to form the gut’s nervous system. Researchers found that endothelin-3 triggers electrical oscillations via T-type calcium channels, enabling these cells to contract like ‘mini muscles’ and colonize organs.

items.title: Low temperature and rapid photothermal oxidation of liquid gallium for circular hydrogen production
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 20 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68664-1 Photothermal reactions between liquid gallium and water or seawater enable hydrogen production under light exposure. The authors show that the metal can be regenerated electrochemically, supporting a reusable and sustainable cycle for hydrogen.

items.title: Higgs mode-driven phase transitions in two-dimensional perovskites
items.summary: Nature Materials, Published online: 20 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02472-8 A study of phase transitions in two-dimensional halide perovskites uncovers distinct thermal and optical pathways through Ginzburg–Landau theory. The work identifies an optically driven metastable tetragonal phase, excited by Higgs phonon modes, offering insights into symmetry-breaking dynamics.

items.title: Nanoscience at the centre of optical computing

items.title: Light could lower AI’s appetite for power
items.summary: Nature Nanotechnology, Published online: 20 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41565-025-02099-5 Optical computing is emerging as a low-power alternative by processing data with light instead of electrons. Advances in metasurfaces, plasmonics, and thin-film lithium niobate enable photonic circuits now being co-integrated with CMOS chips for hybrid, energy-efficient artificial intelligence (AI) computing.

items.title: Nanoparticle-mediated targeting chimeras transform targeted protein degradation

items.summary: Nature, Published online: 19 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00144-4 A study has outlined eight indicators of toxic masculinity in heterosexual men — and finds that ‘manliness’ is not necessarily a problematic aspect of masculinity.

items.summary: Nature, Published online: 19 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00187-7 A fast-paced book captures how theory and formal proof intertwined with the personal lives of prominent mathematicians.

items.title: Driving Floquet physics with excitonic fields
items.summary: Nature Physics, Published online: 19 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41567-025-03132-z Floquet engineering is often limited by weak light–matter coupling and heating. Now it is shown that exciton-driven fields in monolayer semiconductors produce stronger, longer-lived Floquet effects and reveal hybridization linked to excitonic phases.

items.title: Long-range chemical signalling in vivo is regulated by mechanical signals

items.title: Cell viscosity influences haematogenous dissemination and metastatic extravasation of tumour cells
items.summary: Nature Materials, Published online: 19 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02462-w The viscosity of tumour cells is shown to govern their ability to disseminate through the bloodstream and extravasate, establishing a key biomechanical factor of metastasis.

items.title: Spatiotemporal targeting of messenger RNA lipid nanoparticles to the endometrium for the treatment of reproductive disorders
